fields.description:
enable SCP traffic passing between instances in cloud
network mode EDGE
fields.summary: possibility to pass SCTP traffic between instances

comments.body:
Hi
If we can get this to only to VPC that would be ok.
Ref to support ticket:
https://support.eucalyptus.com/hc/en-us/requests/929

VPC lets security group rules refer to protocols by number, making it possible to use protocols other than the usual three.  [~nurmi] indicated that the back end ought to support that use case already, but we haven't tested it yet.  [~mclark], when you have a chance would you mind giving SCTP a look?
So all we need is bit more relaxed euca2ools version :?

It looks like more than a euca2ools change, this is using boto/eutester... {code} authorize_group_by_name(self, group_name=sctptest, port=0, end_port=1023, protocol=132, cidr_ip=0.0.0.0/0, src_security_group=None, src_security_group_name=None, src_security_group_owner_id=None, force_args=False) [2015-05-05 11:42:35,095] [EUCAOPS] [DEBUG]: Attempting authorization of:sctptest, on port range: 0 to 1023, proto:132 from 0.0.0.0/0 ... ... ... EC2ResponseError: EC2ResponseError: 400 InvalidPermission.Malformed InvalidPermission.MalformedNo enum constant com.eucalyptus.network.NetworkRule.Protocol.13271fc6487-6ba5-4972-9a0e-350f5e1c0931
The euca2ools change required for this is tracked in TOOLS-560.

Hey [~mhelenius], Besides the euca2ools changes required for this (as tracked in TOOLS-560) we might have to change the code at few places in the UFS. One such example as highlighted by [~mclark] is at:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/blob/master/clc/modules/compute-common/src/main/java/com/eucalyptus/compute/common/internal/network/NetworkRule.java#L95
 
+1 to [~mclark] we should try and get this behaviour updated in non-VPC (EC2 Classic) at the earliest. Perhaps this could be done in Euca 4.1.2 itself instead of updating until Euca 4.2.0

Is specific port limiting a requirement here? In AWS VPC you cannot specify specific ports with sctp (protocol 132), that is how it will be implemented for EDGE mode unless there is a specific requirement to the contrary.
[~zhill] Specific port rate limiting is not required, aligned functionality with AWS is adequate. I review the requirements with customer just a minute ago and they are excited already!

Hi [~mhelenius] [~zhill], 
"rate"  above may have been a typo, so want to clarify the proposed behavior for 'port range'.
My understanding (what I'm testing to) is that user provided ports for protocols other than TCP, UDP and ICMP will be ignored.  All ports will be available for SCTP if it is allowed in the security group, and the security group will reflect the lack of port enforcement for these additional protocols in 'describe' requests. This is similar to VPC mode in AWS. 
Thanks!
-M

[~mhelenius] and [~mclark], sounds good! The current behavior is that if the user specifies ports in the 'authorize' request then the ports are ignored and sctp traffic is allowed on all ports. This is consistent with AWS VPC behavior.

Fix pushed. Test using protocol '132'. I manually tested in EDGE mode for add, remove security group rules with and without source CIDRs.

Also verified that unsupported protocols for EDGE respond with nice message "Protocol X not supported in EC2-Classic compatible mode".

Hi [~zhill], 
Any remaining items to be checked in on this one, or is it ready for final testing?
Thanks!
-M

[~mclark], follow-up commit went in just now. Adds the following:

# Restricts ports to only be allowed for udp, tcp, and icmp, all other protocols will ignore ports provided by the user and not persist them in the db. This is consistent with AWS VPC behavior.
# Adds a configurable property: cloud.network.ec2_classic_additional_protocols_allowed that is a list of numbers (e.g "132, 133, 134" that are the protocol numbers to allow in ec2 classic platform/mode. VPC is unchanged. I have tested with EDGE, but we need to verify that it is safe with managed/managed-novlan as well. I don't expect it to work, but it shouldn't break things. I can do another fix if additional restrictions are needed to prevent configuration of the values in non-EDGE modes.

Need to ensure the following as well: 
* -1 for VPC still allows all protocols. I tested manually and this should work fine as I didn't touch the VPC code path.
* Sending a forbidden/invalid protocol should send a nice error message. I tested this as well for 'sctp', 'fc' and others and it works as expected, but please confirm.
*

Hi [~mhelenius] [~zhill],
Sorry for the late update. 
VPC :
I verified VPC works for both public and private. 
EDGE:
-Similar to before, I was only able to pass SCTP traffic in Edge mode while using the VM's private interface. This included both from VM to VM, or by using a private address range that is reachable/routable from the public network.  (For this cloud the private and public ip ranges are in the same l2 segment as the lab network). 
-I attempted including the sctp iptables module in the accept rule, this did not make a difference. 
-The current guess is something with the D-NATing. Still attempting to log iptables info (I either log too much and lockup the node, or I dont log anything). 


Marko you should see a rule similar to this on the node hosting the VM referencing that security group:
[root@g-26-04 ~]# iptables-save | grep sctp
-A EU_IbrhVMd6i+VZHS5RI8WjTg== -p sctp -j ACCEPT

From the VM using tcpdump, do you see any SCTP traffic making it to the VM? If not do you see anything hitting the node? tcpdump -i any sctp

Thanks, 
-M
In EDGE public IP DNAT seems to require nf_conntrack_proto_sctp module to be loaded NC. After adding that I was able to establish SCTP test between instances using public IP as SCTP destination.

Hi [~teejalon],
I'm currently adding SCTP tests to our continuous integration suite. Could provide a little more detail on how you loaded and used the module? Just insmod or was additional iptables configuration needed? 
Thank you!
-Matt

Just 
#modprobe  nf_conntrack_proto_sctp
For tests in and between instance I used iperf and instructions on http://datatag.web.cern.ch/datatag/WP3/sctp/tests.htm

[~teejalon] [~mhelenius]
Thanks for the info. Testing looked good on my end, marking this one ready for release.
[~tony] what is Affected Version please?

https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.1.2/index.html#release-notes/4.1.2/4.1.2_rn_features.html What's New gives a high-level description of how to use this.

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/BTS/Extending+EC2-Classic+Platform+Security+Group+Protocol+Support provides background info.
